Using wet hands, thread the balls onto the end of the skewers, massaging the mixture down the skewers in between the palms of your hands, until evenly distributed. Ensure that the mixture is fully wrapped tightly around the skewers without any exposed metal. Alternatively, lay them on a large baking tray lined with parchment paper if cooking in the oven, or foil if cooking under the grill. Shape into 20cm-long kÃ¶fte. Wet your fingers with a little cold water and make indents all along the kÃ¶fte for the traditional shape.
step 3

Gently brush each kÃ¶fte with the remaining 1 tbsp oil and cook under the grill, on the top shelf for 10-12 mins, turning regularly, or cook in the oven for 16-18 mins, until crispy on the outside and juicy in the middle

name: Air fryer patatas bravas
steps: step 1

Soak the potatoes in just-boiled water for 30 mins, then drain and leave to air-dry for 5 mins. Heat the air fryer to 200C. Tip the potatoes into a bowl and drizzle over 1 tbsp of the oil and add 1/2 tsp each of salt and freshly ground black pepper. Mix to coat the potatoes all over, then tip into the air fryer basket and cook for 20-30 mins until crisp and golden.
step 2

Meanwhile, heat the remaining oil in a small pan over a medium-low heat and fry the onion for 8-10 mins until softened but not golden. Stir in the garlic and cook for a minute before adding the paprika and cooking for 30 seconds more. Stir in the tomato purÃ©e, cook for 1 min, then tip in the chopped tomatoes. Cook for 5-10 mins over a medium heat until thickened slightly.
step 3
Once the potatoes are cooked, tip out onto a platter and pour over the tomato sauce. Sprinkle with the basil leaves, then serve.

name: Ajo blanco
steps: step 1
Tip the bread into a bowl and pour over 350ml water. Leave to soak for 10 mins.
step 2
Blend the ingredients together with 350ml water and 1 tsp salt.
step 3
Let the soup cool in the fridge for 1 hr or so, then serve with a drizzle of oil and some black pepper.

name: Alfajores
steps: Make the "Dough": Cream butter and sugar. Add egg yolks and lemon zest. Gradually mix in flour and cornstarch to form a dough. Chill for 1 hour.
Bake the "Cookies": Roll out the dough, cut into circles, and bake at 180Â°C (350Â°F) for 12-15 minutes. Let cool.
Assemble: Spread dulce de leche on one cookie, then sandwich with another. Roll the edges in coconut flakes.
Pro "Tips":
Chill the dough before rolling it out to make it easier to handle and to prevent the cookies from spreading too much while baking.
Dip the alfajores in melted chocolate and let them set on a wire rack for an extra decadent treat.

name: Algerian Bouzgene Berber Bread with Roasted Pepper Sauce
steps: Preheat your oven's broiler. Place red bell peppers and tomatoes on a baking sheet, and roast under the broiler for about 8 minutes, turning occasionally. This should blacken the skin and help it peel off more easily. Cool, then scrape the skins off of the tomatoes and peppers, and place them in a large bowl. Remove cores and seeds from the bell peppers.

Heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Add the jalapenos and garlic, and cook until tender, stirring frequently. Remove from heat, and transfer the garlic and jalapeno to the bowl with the tomatoes and red peppers. Using two sharp steak knives (one in each hand), cut up the tomatoes and peppers to a coarse and soupy consistency. Stir, and set sauce aside.

Place the semolina in a large bowl, and stir in salt and 4 tablespoons of olive oil. Gradually add water while mixing and squeezing with your hand until the dough holds together without being sticky or dry, and molds easily with the hand. Divide into 6 pieces and form into balls.

For each round, heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil in a large heavy skillet over medium heat. Roll out dough one round at a time, to no thicker than 1/4 inch. Fry in the hot skillet until dark brown spots appear on the surface, and they are crispy. Remove from the skillet, and wrap in a clean towel while preparing the remaining flat breads.
To eat the bread and sauce, break off pieces of the bread, and scoop them into the sauce. It will slide off, but just keep reaching in!

name: Algerian Carrots
steps: Place a steamer insert into a saucepan, and fill with 1 1/2 cups of water, or just below the bottom of the steamer. Cover, and bring the water to a boil over high heat. Add the sliced carrots, reduce the heat to medium, and cover the pan again. Steam until tender but not mushy, 4 to 6 minutes depending on the thickness of the slices. Reserve 1/2 cup of the cooking liquid.

Heat the olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Reduce the heat to low and stir in the salt, pepper, cinnamon, cumin, garlic, and thyme. Cook the spices and garlic, stirring frequently, until fragrant, about 10 minutes. Add the 1/2 cup reserved cooking liquid and the bay leaf, cover, and simmer for 20 minutes.
Stir in the carrots, tossing well to coat with the spice mixture, and cook until heated through, about 2 to 3 minutes. Sprinkle with lemon juice and remove the bay leaf before serving.

name: Algerian Flafla (Bell Pepper Salad)
steps: Preheat an oven to 450 degrees F (230 degrees C). Place the whole peppers on aluminum foil. Bake until the skin is spotted black and the peppers are soft, 30 to 45 minutes, turning the peppers once if necessary.
Remove peppers from the oven and set aside to cool for 10 minutes. Peel off the skin and remove the stem and seeds. Chop the roasted peppers into half-inch pieces.

Heat the olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Stir in the onion and cook, stirring frequently, until the onion has softened and turned translucent, about 5 minutes. Add the garlic, salt, and pepper; stir in the chopped peppers and tomato. Cook over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until the tomato is soft and the mixture is well incorporated, about 5 minutes.

name: Algerian Kefta (Meatballs)
steps: Combine ground beef with 1/2 of the minced garlic and 1 tablespoon chopped onion in a large bowl. Mix with your hands until fully incorporated. Shape meat mixture into 1 1/2-inch oblong patties; you should have 12 to 14 meatballs.

Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Brown patties in batches in the hot skillet until crispy on both sides and no longer pink in the center, about 10 minutes. Set meatballs aside in a rimmed serving dish.

Reduce heat to medium and stir remaining chopped onion into drippings in the skillet. Season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring constantly, until onion has softened and turned translucent, about 5 minutes. Stir in remaining garlic and cook for 30 seconds. Stir in Roma tomatoes, dried parsley, and ras el hanout. Pour in water. Cook until tomatoes are soft, about 5 minutes.
Pour tomato sauce over meatballs to serve.

name: Anzac biscuits
steps: step 1

Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Put the oats, coconut, flour and sugar in a bowl. Melt the butter in a small pan and stir in the golden syrup. Add the bicarbonate of soda to 2 tbsp boiling water, then stir into the golden syrup and butter mixture.
step 2
Make a well in the middle of the dry ingredients and pour in the butter and golden syrup mixture. Stir gently to incorporate the dry ingredients.
step 3
Put dessertspoonfuls of the mixture on to buttered baking sheets, about 2.5cm/1in apart to allow room for spreading. Bake in batches for 8-10 mins until golden. Transfer to a wire rack to cool.

name: Apam balik
steps: Mix milk, oil and egg together. Sift flour, baking powder and salt into the mixture. Stir well until all ingredients are combined evenly.
Spread some batter onto the pan. Spread a thin layer of batter to the side of the pan. Cover the pan for 30-60 seconds until small air bubbles appear.
Add butter, cream corn, crushed peanuts and sugar onto the pancake. Fold the pancake into half once the bottom surface is browned.
Cut into wedges and best eaten when it is warm.

name: Apple & Blackberry Crumble
steps: Heat oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5. Tip the flour and sugar into a large bowl. Add the butter, then rub into the flour using your fingertips to make a light breadcrumb texture. Do not overwork it or the crumble will become heavy. Sprinkle the mixture evenly over a baking sheet and bake for 15 mins or until lightly coloured.

Meanwhile, for the compote, peel, core and cut the apples into 2cm dice. Put the butter and sugar in a medium saucepan and melt together over a medium heat. Cook for 3 mins until the mixture turns to a light caramel. Stir in the apples and cook for 3 mins. Add the blackberries and cinnamon, and cook for 3 mins more. Cover, remove from the heat, then leave for 2-3 mins to continue cooking in the warmth of the pan.
To serve, spoon the warm fruit into an ovenproof gratin dish, top with the crumble mix, then reheat in the oven for 5-10 mins. Serve with vanilla ice cream.

name: Apple Frangipan Tart
steps: Preheat the oven to 200C/180C Fan/Gas 6.

Put the biscuits in a large re-sealable freezer bag and bash with a rolling pin into fine crumbs. Melt the butter in a small pan, then add the biscuit crumbs and stir until coated with butter. Tip into the tart tin and, using the back of a spoon, press over the base and sides of the tin to give an even layer. Chill in the fridge while you make the filling.

Cream together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. You can do this in a food processor if you have one. Process for 2-3 minutes. Mix in the eggs, then add the ground almonds and almond extract and blend until well combined.

Peel the apples, and cut thin slices of apple. Do this at the last minute to prevent the apple going brown. Arrange the slices over the biscuit base. Spread the frangipane filling evenly on top. Level the surface and sprinkle with the flaked almonds.
Bake for 20-25 minutes until golden-brown and set.
Remove from the oven and leave to cool for 15 minutes. Remove the sides of the tin. An easy way to do this is to stand the tin on a can of beans and push down gently on the edges of the tin.
Transfer the tart, with the tin base attached, to a serving plate. Serve warm with cream, crÃ¨me fraiche or ice cream.

name: Apricot & Turkish delight mess
steps: step 1

Place the mascarpone, yogurt, sugar and orange flower water into a large bowl and whisk until thickened. Fold the remaining ingredients through, then divide the mix between 2 dessert glasses or bowls and decorate with extra mint, if you like.

name: Arroz al horno (baked rice)
steps: step 1

Heat oven to 200C/180C/gas 6. Heat half the oil in a deep frying or sautÃ© pan (or shallow casserole dish) measuring around 30cm in diameter. Over a high heat, colour the pork belly slices on each side in several batches, then transfer to a bowl. Add the remaining oil to the pan and lower the heat to medium, then add the black pudding and bacon and fry all over for several mins. Remove with a slotted spoon. Fry the onion and peppers for around 10 mins until soft and pale gold, then add the tomato and cook until soft. Add the garlic, smoked paprika and chilli flakes and cook for another 2 mins, then put the pork, black pudding and bacon back in the pan. Add the beans, stock and whichever herb you're using, and bring everything to the boil.
step 2

Sprinkle the rice around the pork belly, pushing it underneath the stock. Let the stock come to the boil again, season well, then transfer to the oven (leave it uncovered). Cook for 20 mins without stirring, then check to see how the rice is doing. The rice should be tender and the stock absorbed. If itâs not ready, put back in the oven for another 5 mins, then check again. Taste for seasoning.
step 3
Squeeze lemon juice over the top and drizzle over some extra virgin olive oil just before serving, if you like.

name: Arroz con gambas y calamar
steps: step 1

Peel and devein most of the prawns (a fishmonger should be able to do this for you), keeping a few whole for decoration, if you like. Heat the olive oil in a large frying pan or shallow flameproof casserole over a medium-low heat and fry the onion for 5 mins until softened. Add the bay leaf, saffron, rice and tomato purÃ©e, and cook for 1-2 mins more, stirring.
step 2

Pour in the wine and bubble for 1-2 mins, then pour in the seafood stock and 150ml water. Cook for 5 mins, then add the squid, season well and stir to combine. Bring to the boil, then cover and reduce the heat to a gentle simmer. Cook for 12 mins more, adding a little more water if the mixture starts to look dry.
step 3

Uncover the pan and stir through the peeled prawns, then arrange any whole prawns on top of the rice mixture. Cover again and simmer for a further 5-6 mins until the prawns are pink and cooked through. Leave to stand for a couple of minutes before serving from the pan.

name: Asado
steps: Prepare the "Fire": Start a wood fire in your grill and let it burn down to coals.
Season the "Meat": Generously salt the beef cuts.
Grill the "Meat": Place the beef on the grill, starting with the thickest cuts farthest from the coals. Add chorizo and morcilla after the beef has been cooking for a while.
Cook to "Perfection": Cook the meat, turning occasionally, until it reaches your desired doneness. Typically, ribs may take up to 2 hours; thinner cuts will cook faster.
Rest and "Serve": Let the meat rest for about 10 minutes before slicing. Serve with chimichurri sauce and grilled vegetables.
Pro "Tips":
Use a mix of wood and charcoal for a consistent heat source. Wood adds flavor, while charcoal maintains temperature.
Season the meat just before grilling to ensure it retains its moisture and flavor.
Serving "Suggestions":
Serve with a side of chimichurri sauce, a fresh tomato salad, and crusty bread. Pair with a robust Malbec wine to complement the rich flavors of the meat.

name: Aubergine & hummus grills
steps: step 1

Lay the aubergine out in one layer on a large baking sheet. Brush sparingly with vegetable oil, then season generously. Grill for 15 mins, turning twice and brushing with oil until the slices are softened and cooked through. Meanwhile, whizz the bread into crumbs. Add 2 tsp oil and whizz briefly again, to coat.
step 2

Spread a couple of tsps of hummus on top of each slice of aubergine. Tip the breadcrumbs onto a large plate, then press the hummus side of the aubergines into the crumbs to coat. Grill again, crumb-side up, for about 3 mins until golden.
step 3
Toss the walnuts, parsley and cherry tomatoes in a bowl, season, then add the lemon juice and olive oil and toss again. Serve the grills with the salad, a dollop more hummus and some pitta bread.

name: Aubergine couscous salad
steps: step 1
Heat grill to high. Put the aubergine on a baking sheet, brush with oil and season. Grill for about 15 mins, turning and brushing with more oil halfway, until browned and softened.
step 2

Meanwhile, tip the couscous into a large bowl, pour over the stock, then cover and leave for 10 mins. Mix the tomatoes, mint, goatâs cheese and remaining oil together. Fluff the couscous up with a fork, then stir in the aubergines, tomato mixture and lemon juice.

name: Aussie Burgers
steps: step 1

Make the "burgers": Tip the meat into a bowl and sprinkle over 1 tsp salt and a good grinding of black pepper.Work with wet hands to mix in the seasoning. Divide into four with your hands and shape into burgers. (It can be frozen at this stage.)
step 2
Sort out your "ingredients": Slice the beetroot and split the naan breads.
step 3

Toast the "naans": Heat a griddle pan or barbecue. Griddle the naans on both sides until lightly toasted and set aside. Add the burgers to the grill or barbecue and cook for 2-3 minutes, then turn and cook the other side for a further 2-3 minutes.
step 4

Assemble the "dish": Set half a toasted naan on each serving plate and put a pile of rocket on each. Top with a burger, then a few slices of beetroot and a dollop of soured cream. Sprinkle with salt and freshly ground black pepper and serve immediately with a big green salad and chips. A glass of red wine wouldnât go amiss, either.

name: Authentic Norwegian Kransekake
steps: Grind almonds in an almond grinder or food processor.

Mix almonds and powdered sugar together in a large mixing bowl. Add three of the egg whites and knead the dough together with your hands until it comes together in a ball. Wrap in cling film and leave in the fridge for at least an hour, preferably until the next day.
Grease the kransekake forms thoroughly and coat with semolina, flour, or bread crumbs.
Preheat oven to 210Â°C (410Â°F) top and bottom heat. Divide the dough into six sections.

Slowly add the remaining egg white to the dough and knead it until you can roll it into long sausages about as thick as your index finger. Fill the forms with the dough sausages, pinching the ends together to make rings.
Set the forms on a baking sheet and back in the middle of the oven for about 10 â 12 minutes, until the tops are golden brown.

name: Avocado dip with new potatoes
steps: step 1

Whizz half the avocado flesh with the yogurt, lime and lemon juice and seasoning. Dice the remaining avocado, then gently stir into the whizzed mix with most of the lime zest. Cover, then chill until ready to serve.
step 2
Boil potatoes for 6 mins, then drain well and toss with olive oil, chilli powder and cumin seeds. Now set aside until half an hour before your guests arrive.
step 3

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6, then roast potatoes for about 30 mins, shaking the tray halfway, until golden and tender. Transfer the dip to one or two bowls, scatter with the remaining lime zest and serve with the hot potatoes, and tortilla chips for dipping.

name: Ayam Percik
steps: In a blender, add the ingredients for the spice paste and blend until smooth.

Over medium heat, pour the spice paste in a skillet or pan and fry for 10 minutes until fragrant. Add water or oil 1 tablespoon at a time if the paste becomes too dry. Don't burn the paste. Lower the fire slightly if needed.

Add the cloves, cardamom, tamarind pulp, coconut milk, water, sugar and salt. Turn the heat up and bring the mixture to boil. Turn the heat to medium low and simmer for 10 minutes. Stir occasionally. It will reduce slightly. This is the marinade/sauce, so taste and adjust seasoning if necessary. Don't worry if it's slightly bitter. It will go away when roasting.
When the marinade/sauce has cooled, pour everything over the chicken and marinate overnight to two days.
Preheat the oven to 425 F.

Remove the chicken from the marinade. Spoon the marinade onto a greased (or aluminum lined) baking sheet. Lay the chicken on top of the sauce (make sure the chicken covers the sauce and the sauce isn't exposed or it'll burn) and spread the remaining marinade on the chicken. Roast for 35-45 minutes or until internal temp of the thickest part of chicken is at least 175 F.
Let chicken rest for 5 minutes. Brush the chicken with some of the oil. Serve chicken with the sauce over steamed rice (or coconut rice).

name: Tunisian Street-Style Sandwich
ingredients: A few slices tomato and cucumber
steps: Slice the roll lengthwise without cutting it completely.
Drizzle the inside with a little olive oil.
Spread tuna along the bread, then add potato slices.
Add tomato, cucumber, olives and egg.
Season with salt and finish with harissa according to taste.
note: Typical Tunisian snack sold in street stands; easy and fast for busy evenings.

name: Couscous with Vegetables (Moroccan style)
ingredients: 2 carrots, peeled and cut in sticks
Salt, pepper and mild spices (ras el hanout)
steps: Prepare a light vegetable broth with onion, carrots, turnips and spices.
Add courgette and chickpeas towards the end.
Steam couscous above the broth until grains are fluffy.
Serve couscous in a large dish and pour vegetables and broth on top.
note: Light North African couscous - ideal for family dinners and Ramadan evenings.

name: Tunisian Couscous with Vegetable Broth
steps: Brown meat and onion in olive oil.
Add tomato paste, harissa and spices; cook a few minutes.
Add vegetables and enough water to make a fragrant broth, simmer until tender.
Steam couscous over the broth, then serve with meat and vegetables on top.
note: National Tunisian dish with a rich red broth, perfect for big family meals.

name: Salade Tunisienne Classique
ingredients: 1 small can tuna in oil, drained
steps: Place tomatoes, cucumber, onion and green pepper in a bowl.
Season with salt, pepper, olive oil and lemon juice, then mix gently.
Add tuna and olives on top and serve fresh.
note: Basic everyday Tunisian salad - perfect starter with bread and harissa.

name: Fattoush - Lebanese Bread Salad
ingredients: 2 pieces pita bread, toasted or fried
steps: Toast or fry pita bread until golden, then break into pieces.
In a large bowl, mix lettuce, tomatoes, cucumber, radishes and onion.
Whisk olive oil, lemon juice, sumac, salt and pepper to make the dressing.
Add bread pieces and dressing just before serving, toss and serve immediately.
note: Crunchy and fresh salad from the Levant - great with grilled meat.

name: Harira - Simple Moroccan Soup
ingredients: 150 g small pieces of lamb or beef (optional)
2 grated tomatoes or 300 g tomato pulp
Flour mixed with water to thicken (2 tbsp)
steps: SautÃ© meat (if using), onion and celery in olive oil until softened.
Add grated tomatoes, tomato paste, ginger, turmeric, cinnamon, salt and pepper; cook a few minutes.
Add lentils, chickpeas and enough water; simmer until lentils are almost tender.
Add vermicelli and cook a few minutes more.
Pour in flour-water mixture while stirring to thicken, then finish with coriander and parsley.
note: Traditional Moroccan soup, especially served at iftar during Ramadan.

name: Chorba Frik - Algerian Soup with Green Wheat
ingredients: 250 g lamb or beef with bone
steps: Brown meat and onion in a little olive oil.
Add grated tomatoes and tomato paste; cook a few minutes.
Cover with water, add carrot, frik, turmeric, cinnamon, salt and pepper.
Simmer until meat and frik are tender.
Finish with chopped herbs just before serving.
note: Comforting Algerian soup - very popular in winter and Ramadan.

name: Chicken Tajine with Preserved Lemons
ingredients: 1 whole chicken cut in pieces or 1 kg chicken pieces
steps: In a tajine or pot, mix chicken with onions, garlic, spices, salt and olive oil.
Cook a few minutes while turning the chicken until slightly colored.
Add a little water, cover and simmer until chicken is almost tender.
Add olives and preserved lemon; continue cooking until sauce is reduced and chicken soft.
Finish with chopped herbs if desired and serve with bread.
note: Classic Moroccan tajine - salty lemon and olives give a strong flavor.

name: Tunisian Baked Tajine with Merguez
ingredients: 4-5 merguez sausages, sliced or cooked and cut
Olive oil for greasing the dish
steps: Preheat oven to 180Â°C and grease a baking dish with olive oil.
In a bowl, mix eggs, grated cheese, parsley, salt, pepper and harissa if using.
Add diced potatoes and merguez pieces, then mix well.
Pour the mixture into the dish and smooth the top.
Bake until set and golden on top, then cool slightly before cutting into squares.
note: Tunisian tajine is like a thick oven omelette, often served as starter or for picnics.

name: Tunisian Couscous with Fish
steps: Brown onion in olive oil, then add tomato paste and harissa; cook a few minutes.
Add water, carrots, potatoes, peppers and spices; simmer until vegetables are almost tender.
Add fish pieces to the broth and cook gently until done.
Steam couscous grains over the broth, fluff with a little oil.
Serve couscous in a large dish, arrange vegetables and fish on top, pour some broth.
note: Spicy coastal version of couscous, very common in Tunisia.

name: Couscous with Seven Vegetables
steps: SautÃ© meat and onion in olive oil with ginger, turmeric, salt and pepper.
Add water and chickpeas, simmer until meat is partially cooked.
Add all vegetables cut in large pieces, cook gently until tender.
Steam couscous grains above the pot 2-3 times, sprinkling with salted water and fluffing between stages.
Serve couscous on a large platter with meat, vegetables and some broth over the top.
note: Traditional Friday couscous in many Moroccan families.

name: Menemen - Turkish Eggs with Tomatoes and Peppers
steps: Heat oil or butter in a pan and sautÃ© onion (if using) and green pepper until soft.
Add chopped tomatoes, salt, pepper and paprika; cook until tomatoes form a sauce.
Beat eggs lightly in a bowl and pour into the pan.
Stir gently until eggs are just set but still soft, then serve immediately with bread.
note: Very popular Turkish breakfast, also good as a quick light dinner.

name: Quick Tomato and Basil Pasta
steps: Cook pasta in salted boiling water according to package instructions.
Meanwhile, sautÃ© garlic in olive oil until fragrant but not burnt.
Add crushed tomatoes, salt, pepper and a pinch of sugar; simmer 10 minutes.
Add chopped basil, then toss pasta with the sauce.
Serve hot with Parmesan if desired.
note: Simple everyday pasta dish, easy base to customize.

name: Chicken Tikka Masala - Home Version
ingredients: 600 g chicken breast, cut in cubes
2 tbsp tikka masala or curry spice mix
steps: Marinate chicken in yogurt and spice mix for at least 30 minutes.
Brown marinated chicken in a pan, then set aside.
In the same pan, sautÃ© onion, garlic and ginger until soft.
Add tomato puree, salt, pepper and a little garam masala; simmer a few minutes.
Return chicken to the pan, add cream or coconut milk and cook until chicken is done and sauce thick.
Serve with rice and garnish with fresh coriander.
note: Adapted version of a famous Indian-inspired dish - very popular worldwide.

name: Ratatouille - Mediterranean Vegetable Stew
ingredients: 3 tomatoes, chopped or 300 g tomato pulp
steps: Heat olive oil in a large pan and sautÃ© onion and garlic.
Add aubergine, courgette and pepper; cook a few minutes while stirring.
Add tomatoes, herbs, salt and pepper.
Lower heat, cover and cook slowly until vegetables are soft and flavors combined.
Serve hot or warm with bread, rice or grilled meat.
note: Classic vegetable dish from the south of France - also good as side dish.

name: Ojja with Merguez - Tunisian Egg Dish
steps: Brown merguez slices in a pan with a little olive oil, then set aside.
In the same pan, sautÃ© onion and garlic until soft.
Add tomatoes, tomato paste, harissa, salt, pepper and cumin; cook until sauce thickens.
Return merguez to the pan and mix.
Make small wells in the sauce and crack eggs on top; cover and cook until eggs are just set.
Serve immediately with crusty bread.
note: Very popular Tunisian pan dish, often eaten with bread directly from the pan.

name: Tunisian Brik with Egg and Tuna
steps: Mix tuna, parsley and capers; season with salt and pepper.
Place one sheet of pastry on a plate and put a spoon of filling in the centre.
Make a small hollow in the filling and crack an egg into it.
Fold the pastry to close the brik into a triangle or half-moon.
Fry in hot oil until golden and crisp on both sides, then drain on paper.
Serve hot with lemon wedges.
note: Classic starter during Ramadan evenings and in Tunisian snack bars.

name: Simple Homemade Beef Burger
steps: Season ground beef with salt and pepper, shape into 2 patties.
Cook patties in a pan or on a grill until done; place cheese slices on top at the end to melt.
Lightly toast burger buns.
Assemble burgers with lettuce, tomato, pickles, patty with cheese and sauces.
Serve immediately with fries or salad.
note: Basic homemade burger - easy to adapt with extra toppings.

name: Chicken Veggie Wrap
steps: Lay tortillas flat and spread yogurt sauce or mayonnaise.
Add lettuce, chicken slices, tomato, cucumber and corn.
Season with salt and pepper.
Roll tightly into wraps and cut in half diagonally.
Serve fresh as a quick lunch or light dinner.
note: Flexible wrap - you can add leftovers and different vegetables.

name: Fluffy American Pancakes
ingredients: Maple syrup or honey for serving
steps: Mix flour, sugar, baking powder and salt in a bowl.
In another bowl, whisk milk, egg and melted butter.
Combine wet and dry ingredients; do not overmix (small lumps are OK).
Cook small rounds of batter in a greased hot pan until bubbles form on top, then flip and cook the other side.
Serve stacked with maple syrup or honey.
note: Perfect for weekend breakfasts, especially with children.

name: Orange and Almond Moist Cake
steps: Beat eggs with sugar until pale and slightly thick.
Add oil, orange juice and zest, then mix.
Fold in flour, baking powder and ground almonds.
Pour the batter into a greased and floured tin.
Bake at 180Â°C for about 30-35 minutes, or until a skewer comes out clean.
Cool, then dust with icing sugar before serving.
note: Fragrant, moist cake often served with mint tea or coffee.

name: Fresh Mixed Fruit Salad
ingredients: A few strawberries or seasonal fruits
steps: Prepare all fruits and cut them into bite-size pieces.
Place fruits in a large bowl and sprinkle with lemon juice to avoid browning.
Add sugar or honey if desired and mix gently.
Serve fresh, or refrigerate for a short time before serving.
note: Simple way to use seasonal fruits - good dessert after a heavy meal.

name: Moroccan Tomato and Onion Salad
steps: Mix tomatoes, onion and parsley.
Season with olive oil, lemon juice, salt and pepper.
Serve fresh.
note: Very simple Moroccan salad served daily.

name: Cold Rice Salad
steps: Mix all ingredients.
Season with salt and pepper.
Serve cold.
note: Classic summer salad prepared in minutes.

name: Classic Chakchouka
steps: SautÃ© onion and peppers in olive oil.
Add tomatoes, season and cook until soft.
Break eggs on top and let them set.
Serve hot with bread.

name: Roast Chicken with Herbs
steps: Rub chicken with butter, herbs, salt and pepper.
Place garlic cloves inside the chicken.
Bake at 200Â°C for about 55 minutes.
Let rest 10 minutes before serving.
note: French style family roast for Sundays.

name: Creamy Potato Gratin
steps: Rub a baking dish with garlic, then arrange potato slices.
Pour cream over, season with salt and pepper and sprinkle cheese.
Bake at 180Â°C until potatoes are tender and top is golden.
note: Classic French side dish served with meat or salad.

name: Makroud with Dates
steps: Prepare a soft semolina dough with oil and water.
Stuff with date paste and shape into long rolls, then cut into diamonds.
Fry until golden and dip in warm honey.
note: Traditional Maghrebi sweet served on holidays and ceremonies.

name: Zlabia
steps: Prepare a fermented batter with flour, yeast and water.
Pipe into hot oil to form spirals and fry until crisp.
Dip the hot zlabia in saffron sugar syrup and let drain.
note: Very sweet fried pastry made especially during Ramadan evenings.

name: Lebanese Chicken Shawarma
ingredients: Garlic sauce and salad for serving
steps: Marinate chicken with spices, lemon, yogurt and oil for at least 30 minutes.
Cook marinated chicken in a pan until golden and cooked through.
Fill pita bread with chicken, salad and garlic sauce.
Serve warm.
note: World famous Lebanese street food, easy to prepare at home.

name: Moroccan Fish Couscous
steps: Prepare a tomato broth with onion, tomatoes, carrots, spices, salt and olive oil.
Add fish pieces and cook gently until just done.
Steam couscous grains and fluff them with a little oil.
Serve couscous with fish and broth on top.
note: Moroccan coastal version of couscous with lighter flavor.

name: Classic Hummus Dip
steps: Blend chickpeas, tahini, lemon juice and garlic.
Add cold water little by little until smooth and creamy.
Season with salt and a pinch of cumin.
Serve in a bowl with olive oil on top.
note: Basic mezze dish served with pita bread and raw vegetables.

name: Chicken Tajine with Olives & Preserved Lemon
steps: Mix chicken with spices and onions; marinate 30 minutes.
SautÃ© chicken in olive oil until lightly browned.
Add preserved lemon slices and olives.
Add a little water and simmer covered until chicken is tender.
note: Classic Moroccan Tajine with a bright lemony flavor.

name: Algerian Chorba Frik
steps: Brown meat and onion with spices.
Add tomatoes and tomato paste, sautÃ© briefly.
Add water, carrots and frik; simmer until tender.
Finish with chopped herbs before serving.
note: Traditional Algerian soup especially served during Ramadan.

name: Tunisian Ojja with Merguez
steps: Cook merguez in a pan until browned.
Add onion and garlic; sautÃ© a few minutes.
Add tomatoes and harissa; simmer until thick.
Crack eggs on top and cook to preferred doneness.
note: Fast Tunisian dishâperfect for quick lunches.

name: Mhadjeb (Semolina Flatbread Stuffed with Tomato & Onion)
steps: Knead semolina with water and oil into a soft dough.
Cook onion, tomato and harissa into a thick filling.
Roll dough thin, place filling, fold and seal.
Cook folded mhadjeb on a hot pan until golden.
note: Popular Algerian street food with a spicy tomato filling.

name: Moroccan Lentil Soup (Harira Style)
steps: SautÃ© onion with spices and tomatoes.
Add lentils, tomato paste and water.
Simmer until lentils are soft.
Adjust seasoning and serve hot.
note: Simplified, hearty lentil soup inspired by Moroccan Harira.

name: Slata Mechouia (Grilled Vegetable Salad)
steps: Grill peppers and tomatoes until skins blacken.
Peel and chop vegetables finely.
Mix with garlic, spices and olive oil.
Top with tuna and olives if desired.

name: Algerian Rechta
steps: Cook chicken with butter, onion and spices.
Add water and chickpeas; simmer until chicken is tender.
Steam rechta noodles over the broth.
Serve noodles topped with chicken and chickpeas.
note: Festive Algerian dish, often served in celebrations.

name: Zaalouk (Moroccan Eggplant Salad)
steps: Peel and dice eggplants, cook with tomatoes and garlic.
Add spices and olive oil.
Mash lightly and simmer until thick.
Serve warm or cold.
note: Popular Moroccan cooked salad served as a starter.

name: Tunisian Spiced Rice with Chicken
steps: Brown chicken in oil; remove and reserve.
SautÃ© onion and tomato paste.
Add rice, spices and water.
Return chicken on top and cook until rice absorbs all liquid.
note: Typical Tunisian family dish, spiced and hearty.

name: Lham Lahlou (Sweet Lamb with Prunes)
steps: Brown lamb in butter with onions.
Add water, sugar, cinnamon and simmer.
Add prunes and cook until sauce becomes syrupy.
Finish with a splash of orange blossom water.
note: Ramadan specialty in Algeria, sweet and fragrant.

name: Kafteji (Fried Vegetable Mix)
steps: Fry vegetables separately until soft.
Chop everything into small cubes.
Mix together with spices.
Top with chopped fried eggs.
note: Classic Tunisian street dish served in sandwiches or plates.

name: Moroccan Chicken Pastilla
steps: Cook chicken with onions and spices until tender.
Shred chicken and mix with beaten eggs and herbs.
Layer filo sheets with butter and filling.
Bake until golden and crisp.
note: Festive Moroccan dish mixing sweet and savory flavors.

name: Bourek with Minced Meat
steps: Cook minced meat with onion and spices.
Mix with parsley and egg.
Fill dioul sheets and roll tightly.
Fry until golden.
note: Traditional Algerian starter served especially during Ramadan.

name: FricassÃ© Tunisien
steps: Prepare soft dough and let rise.
Shape small buns and fry until golden.
Fill with tuna, potato, harissa and olives.
note: Iconic Tunisian fried sandwich served everywhere.

name: Rfissa with Chicken and Lentils
steps: Cook chicken with onions, spices, lentils and fenugreek.
Layer msemen pieces on a large dish.
Pour hot broth and chicken on top.
Serve steaming.
note: Traditional Moroccan dish served for celebrations and postpartum.

name: Algerian Couscous with Chicken
steps: Cook chicken with onion and spices.
Add vegetables and chickpeas.
Steam couscous until fluffy.
Serve couscous with broth and chicken.
note: Milder and lighter than Tunisian couscous.

name: Makrouna Arbi (Tunisian Pasta)
steps: Brown meat with onion and spices.
Add tomato paste, harissa and water to make a sauce.
Cook pasta separately.
Mix pasta with sauce and simmer a few minutes.

name: Harcha (Moroccan Semolina Bread)
steps: Mix semolina with sugar, salt and oil.
Add milk to form a dough.
Shape into disks and cook on a warm pan.
Serve with honey or cheese.

name: Tlitli (Algerian Pasta Grains)
steps: Cook chicken with butter, onion and spices.
Add chickpeas and water.
Steam tlitli over broth.
Serve pasta with chicken and broth.
note: Warm family dish popular in eastern Algeria.

name: Yoyos (Tunisian Honey Doughnuts)
steps: Mix all ingredients to make a soft dough.
Shape rings and fry until golden.
Dip in warm honey or syrup.
Let drain before serving.
note: Tunisian sweet served during Ramadan and celebrations.

name: Shakshouka Tunisienne
steps: SautÃ© onion and pepper in olive oil.
Add tomatoes, tomato paste, harissa, salt and pepper.
Cook until sauce thickens.
Make small holes and crack eggs.
Cover and cook until eggs set.
note: Everyday Tunisian breakfast or dinner dish.

name: Zaalouk - Moroccan Eggplant Salad
steps: Cook eggplant in oil until soft.
Add tomatoes, garlic and spices.
Mash slightly and cook until thick.
Serve warm or cold.
note: A must-have mezze in Moroccan homes.

name: Rechta - Algerian White Chicken Pasta
steps: Cook chicken with onions, butter, salt, pepper and cinnamon.
Add vegetables and water.
Steam rechta noodles over the broth.
Serve noodles topped with chicken and white sauce.

name: Lablebi - Tunisian Chickpea Bowl
steps: Boil chickpeas with garlic and spices.
Place bread pieces in bowls.
Pour boiling chickpeas and broth over bread.
Add egg, harissa and olive oil.
Serve with lemon.

name: Bissara - Moroccan Fava Bean Soup
steps: Boil fava beans with garlic until soft.
Blend until smooth.
Season with cumin, paprika, salt and pepper.
Serve with olive oil on top.

name: Mhajeb - Algerian Stuffed Semolina Crepes
steps: Make soft dough with semolina, water and salt.
Cook onion, tomato and pepper with paprika.
Shape dough into thin squares.
Fill and fold into rectangles.
Cook on hot pan with oil.
note: Algerian street food similar to msemen but stuffed.

name: Salade Mechouia - Tunisian Grilled Salad
steps: Grill tomatoes and peppers until charred.
Peel and blend with garlic.
Season with salt and olive oil.
Top with tuna and olives.
note: Spicy grilled salad typical of Tunisia.

name: Batbout - Moroccan Mini Breads
steps: Mix flour, semolina, yeast, sugar and salt.
Add water to form soft dough.
Cut into small disks and rise.
Cook on hot pan until puffed.

name: Berkoukes - Algerian Pearl Couscous Soup
steps: Cook onion and vegetables with spices.
Add tomato paste and water.
Add chickpeas and berkoukes.
Simmer until grains are tender.
note: Traditional warming soup from rural Algeria.

name: Kabkabou - Tunisian Fish in Tomato Sauce
steps: Cook onion and garlic in olive oil.
Add tomatoes, tomato paste, lemon slices and spices.
Add fish and simmer gently.
Serve with bread or rice.
note: Light Tunisian fish dish cooked in lemony tomato sauce.

name: Mercimek ÃorbasÄ± - Turkish Red Lentil Soup
steps: SautÃ© onion in olive oil.
Add carrot, potato and tomato paste.
Add lentils, water, salt and spices.
Cook until soft then blend smooth.

name: Gratin Dauphinois
steps: Rub a baking dish with garlic and butter.
Layer potatoes with salt, pepper and nutmeg.
Pour cream over the potatoes.
Bake at 180Â°C until soft and golden.

name: Dal Tadka - Indian Yellow Lentils
steps: Boil lentils with turmeric and salt.
Fry onion, garlic, cumin seeds and tomato.
Combine fried mixture with lentils.
Simmer a few minutes and serve.

name: Harcha - Moroccan Semolina Pan Bread
steps: Mix semolina, sugar, salt and baking powder.
Add melted butter and milk to form dough.
Shape small disks and cook on a hot pan.
note: Served with cheese, honey or jam.

name: Tajine Sebnekh - Tunisian Spinach Bake
steps: SautÃ© onions in olive oil.
Add spinach and cook until water evaporates.
Mix eggs, cheese and spices.
Combine with spinach and bake until set.

name: Garantita - Algerian Chickpea Baked Dish
steps: Mix chickpea flour with water.
Add eggs, oil, salt, pepper and cumin.
Bake until top is golden.
Serve with harissa.
note: Popular Algerian street food sold in sandwiches.

name: Tabbouleh - Lebanese Parsley Salad
steps: Soak bulgur in a little water.
Mix parsley, tomato and onion.
Add bulgur, lemon juice and olive oil.
Season and serve.
note: Fresh and light mezze essential in Lebanese cuisine.

name: Minestrone - Italian Vegetable Soup
steps: SautÃ© onion and carrots.
Add potatoes, courgette and tomato pulp.
Add water and simmer.
Add pasta and cook until soft.
note: Hearty Italian soup with mixed vegetables.

name: Simit - Turkish Sesame Bread Rings
steps: Make dough with flour, yeast, salt and water.
Shape rings.
Dip in molasses water then sesame.
Bake until golden.
note: Most famous breakfast bread in Turkey.

name: Quiche Lorraine
steps: Pre-bake the crust.
Cook lardons.
Mix eggs, cream, salt and nutmeg.
Combine and bake until set.

name: Riz Jerbi - Tunisian Herbed Rice
ingredients: 200 g spinach or parsley mix, chopped
steps: Mix rice with chopped herbs, vegetables and spices.
Add meat if using.
Place everything in a couscoussier and steam 45-60 min.
Fluff and serve.
note: Traditional island-style rice dish from Djerba.

name: Bourek - Algerian Fried Meat Rolls
steps: Cook meat with onion and spices.
Add parsley and egg.
Fill pastry sheets and roll tightly.
Fry until golden.

name: Chicken Pastilla - Simple Version
steps: Cook chicken with onion and spices.
Assemble layers of phyllo and chicken.
Brush with butter.
Bake until golden.
note: Simplified version of the famous Moroccan pastilla.

name: Hummus - Lebanese Chickpea Puree
steps: Blend chickpeas, tahini, garlic and lemon.
Add salt and adjust texture with water.
Serve with olive oil on top.
note: Essential mezze found all across the Middle East.

name: Pasta al Pesto - Basil Sauce
steps: Blend basil, garlic, Parmesan and nuts with oil.
Cook pasta until al dente.
Mix pasta with pesto.
Serve immediately.
note: Classic bright-green pasta sauce from Genoa.

name: Butter Chicken - Easy Home Version
steps: Cook onion and garlic in butter.
Add chicken and spices.
Add tomato puree and simmer.
Add cream and cook until thick.
note: Rich, creamy, globally famous Indian dish.

name: Tortilla EspaÃ±ola - Potato Omelette
steps: Cook potatoes and onion slowly in olive oil.
Beat eggs and mix with potatoes.
Cook in pan on both sides.
Serve warm or cold.
note: Iconic Spanish dish served as tapa or meal.

name: Greek Salad - Village Style
steps: Combine tomatoes, cucumber and onion.
Add olives and feta.
Season with olive oil and oregano.

name: Chakchouka Bel Foul - Green Bean Stew
steps: Cook onion in olive oil.
Add tomatoes, paste and spices.
Add beans and water.
Simmer until tender.

name: Couscous Tfaya - Sweet Onion & Raisin Topping
steps: Steam couscous as usual.
Cook onions with butter, raisins, cinnamon and sugar.
Top couscous with sweet onion mixture.
note: Algerian couscous with sweet festive topping.

name: KÃ¶fte - Turkish Grilled Meatballs
steps: Mix all ingredients well.
Shape small oval patties.
Grill or pan-cook until browned.
Serve with bread or rice.
note: Classic Turkish meatballs found everywhere from homes to street grills.

name: Bruschetta al Pomodoro - Tomato Toast
steps: Toast bread slices.
Rub garlic on warm bread.
Top with diced tomatoes, basil and olive oil.
Serve immediately.
note: Famous Italian antipasto, very quick and fresh.

name: Khobz Dar - Moroccan Home Bread
steps: Mix flour, yeast, sugar, salt and water.
Knead and let rise.
Shape 2 round loaves and score tops.
Bake until golden.

name: Mtabga - Tunisian Stuffed Flatbread
steps: Prepare dough and let rest.
Cook onion, tomato and filling with spices.
Roll dough, fill and fold.
Cook on hot pan with a little oil.

name: Makrout - Semolina & Date Cookies
steps: Mix semolina and butter.
Shape rolls filled with date paste.
Cut into diamonds and fry or bake.
Dip in warm honey.

name: Tzatziki - Greek Yogurt Cucumber Dip
steps: Mix yogurt, cucumber and garlic.
Add olive oil and dill.
Season and refrigerate.
note: Served cold with bread or grilled meat.

name: Aloo Gobi - Potato Cauliflower Curry
steps: SautÃ© onion and tomatoes with spices.
Add potatoes and cauliflower.
Cook until tender.
Serve with rice or bread.

name: Gazpacho - Cold Tomato Soup
steps: Blend all vegetables.
Add oil, vinegar and salt.
Chill before serving.

name: Falafel - Lebanese Chickpea Fritters
steps: Blend chickpeas with herbs, onion and spices.
Shape small balls.
Fry until golden.
Serve with tahini sauce.

name: Mousli - Tunisian Toasted Cereal Mix
steps: Toast oats and nuts in butter.
Add honey and mix.
Let cool, then add raisins.
Serve with milk or yogurt.

name: Simit - Turkish Sesame Rings
steps: Mix flour, yeast, sugar, salt and water to form a dough.
Let rise then shape rings.
Dip in molasses-water mixture then sesame seeds.
Bake until golden brown.
note: Iconic Turkish street bread eaten with tea.

name: Baghrir - Moroccan Honey Spongy Pancakes
steps: Blend all ingredients to a smooth batter.
Rest 15 minutes.
Cook on one side only until holes appear.
Serve with melted butter and honey.
note: Served during Ramadan, breakfasts and tea time.

name: Lablabi - Tunisian Chickpea Stew
steps: Heat chickpeas with garlic, cumin, salt and water.
Serve hot over bread pieces.
Top with olive oil, harissa and optional tuna or egg.

name: Rechta - Algerian Homemade Noodles with Chicken
ingredients: Homemade rechta noodles or fresh pasta
steps: Cook chicken with onion, spices and vegetables.
Steam the noodles over the broth.
Serve noodles topped with chicken, vegetables and broth.
note: Festive Algerian dish served at celebrations.

name: Spanakopita - Greek Spinach Pie
steps: SautÃ© spinach and onion until reduced.
Mix with crumbled feta and dill.
Layer filo sheets with oil, add filling.
Bake until golden.
note: A Mediterranean favorite eaten warm or cold.

name: Dal Tadka - Yellow Lentil Curry
steps: Cook lentils with turmeric and salt.
SautÃ© onion, garlic, ginger and spices.
Add tomato then combine with cooked lentils.
Simmer a few minutes and serve with rice.

name: Quiche Lorraine - Savory Egg Pie
steps: Blind-bake pie crust.
Mix eggs, cream, salt, pepper and nutmeg.
Add lardons then pour mixture.
Bake until set and golden.

name: Koshari - Egyptian Lentils, Rice and Pasta
steps: Cook lentils, rice and pasta separately.
Layer in a "bowl": rice, pasta, lentils.
Top with tomato sauce and crispy onions.
Serve hot.
note: National dish of Egypt, very filling and cheap.

name: BÃ¶rek with Cheese - Turkish Savory Pastry
steps: Mix cheese with parsley.
Layer filo sheets with butter or oil.
Add filling, roll or layer.
Pour milk-egg mixture on top and bake.
note: Served at breakfast or dinner, soft inside and crispy outside.

name: Fricasse - Tunisian Stuffed Fried Bun
steps: Prepare dough and let rise.
Shape small buns and fry until golden.
Cut open and fill with potato, tuna, olives and harissa.
Serve warm.
note: A Tunisian favorite sold in snack shops and homes.

name: Shish Taouk - Lebanese Marinated Chicken
steps: Mix yogurt, lemon juice, tomato paste and spices.
Marinate chicken at least 30 minutes.
Skewer and grill until cooked.
Serve with garlic sauce and bread.
note: A Lebanese grill classic, very tender thanks to yogurt.

name: Harsha - Moroccan Semolina Butter Bread
steps: Mix semolina, butter, salt and baking powder.
Add milk to form soft dough.
Cook thick disk on low heat until golden both sides.
Cut and serve with honey or cheese.

name: Kafteji - Tunisian Fried Vegetable Mix
steps: Fry potatoes, courgettes, aubergine and peppers separately.
Chop fried vegetables together.
Cook tomatoes and onion as sauce.
Top with fried eggs and mix.
Serve with harissa and bread.
note: Signature Tunisian street dish served in snacks.

name: Dolma - Algerian Stuffed Vegetables
steps: Mix minced meat with rice, onion and spices.
Stuff vegetables and arrange in pot.
Add tomato sauce and water.
Simmer until vegetables are tender.
Serve hot.

name: Minestrone - Italian Vegetable Soup
steps: SautÃ© vegetables in olive oil.
Add water or broth and simmer.
Add pasta near the end.
Serve hot with Parmesan.
note: Comfort soup eaten all over Italy.

name: Muhammara - Syrian Red Pepper Walnut Dip
steps: Blend peppers, walnuts, tomato paste and garlic.
Add olive oil and spices.
Chill before serving.

name: Tortilla EspaÃ±ola - Potato Omelette
steps: Fry potatoes and onion gently until soft.
Beat eggs and mix with potatoes.
Cook mixture on low heat until set.
Flip carefully and finish cooking.
Serve warm or cold.
note: One of the most famous Spanish dishes.

name: Horiatiki - Greek Village Salad
steps: Cut tomatoes, cucumber, onion and pepper.
Add olives and a slab of feta.
Season with olive oil and oregano.
Serve fresh.
note: Classic Greek salad eaten everywhere in the summer.

name: Shakshuka - Eggs in Spiced Tomato Sauce
steps: Cook onion, garlic and pepper in oil.
Add tomatoes and spices, simmer until thick.
Make small wells and crack eggs.
Cover and cook until eggs set.
Serve with bread.
note: A breakfast or dinner dish similar to Tunisian Ojja.

name: Mercimek Corbasi - Turkish Lentil Soup
steps: SautÃ© onion and carrot in oil.
Add tomato paste and lentils.
Add water and spices, simmer until lentils soften.
Blend or serve as is.
Finish with paprika butter if desired.
note: Most common soup served in Turkish restaurants.

name: Chana Masala - Indian Spiced Chickpeas
steps: Cook onion, garlic and ginger in oil.
Add tomatoes and spices, simmer.
Add chickpeas and a little water.
Cook until sauce thickens.
Serve with rice or bread.

name: Chicken Karahi - Pakistani Wok-Style Chicken
steps: Heat oil and fry chicken until lightly colored.
Add onions, garlic and ginger.
Add tomatoes and spices.
Cook on high heat then reduce until sauce becomes thick.
Serve hot with naan or rice.
note: Signature Pakistani dish cooked in a karahi pan.

name: Miso Soup - Japanese Classic
steps: Heat water without boiling.
Dissolve miso paste.
Add tofu and seaweed.
Serve with chopped spring onion.
note: Very light daily soup served in Japanese meals.

name: Egg Fried Rice - Chinese Style
steps: Scramble eggs in a wok.
Add vegetables and stir-fry.
Add rice and mix quickly.
Season with soy sauce.
Serve hot.
note: A fast meal prepared everywhere in Asia.

name: Green Curry Chicken - Thai Style
steps: Cook curry paste in oil.
Add chicken and stir.
Pour coconut milk and simmer.
Add vegetables and cook until tender.
Serve with rice.
note: One of Thailandâs most fragrant curries.

name: Pho - Vietnamese Noodle Soup
steps: Prepare aromatic broth with spices.
Cook noodles separately.
Place beef slices in bowl.
Pour boiling broth to cook beef instantly.
Add herbs and serve.

name: Bulgogi - Korean Marinated Beef
steps: Marinate beef in soy sauce, garlic, ginger and sugar.
Heat pan and cook beef quickly.
Add sesame oil at the end.
Serve with rice.

name: Simit - Turkish Sesame Bread Rings
steps: Prepare dough with flour, water, sugar and yeast.
Shape rings.
Dip in molasses-water mixture.
Coat in sesame seeds.
Bake until golden.

name: Koshari - Egyptian Lentils, Rice and Pasta Bowl
steps: Cook lentils and rice separately.
Cook pasta.
Prepare spicy tomato sauce.
Assemble rice, lentils and pasta.
Top with crispy onions.

name: Tashreeb - Iraqi Bread and Broth Dish
steps: Cook meat with onion and spices.
Add tomato paste and water.
Simmer into rich broth.
Place bread pieces in deep dish.
Pour hot broth and meat over bread.
note: Comfort Iraqi dish usually served in family gatherings.

name: Mac and Cheese - American Style
steps: Cook macaroni and drain.
Melt butter and add flour to make roux.
Add milk until thick.
Add cheddar and melt.
Mix macaroni with sauce and serve.

name: Poutine - Fries with Gravy and Cheese Curds
steps: Prepare hot crispy fries.
Place cheese curds on top.
Pour hot gravy to melt cheese.
Serve immediately.

name: Chicken Tacos - Mexican Style
steps: Heat tortillas.
Fill with chicken, tomatoes and onion.
Add coriander and lime.
Serve immediately.

name: Feijoada - Brazilian Black Bean Stew
steps: Soak beans if needed.
Cook meat with onions and garlic.
Add beans and simmer until thick.
Serve with rice.

name: Empanadas - Argentine Meat Pockets
steps: Cook meat with spices and onion.
Fill dough circles and close edges.
Bake until golden.
Serve hot.
note: Each Argentinian region has its own style.

name: Ropa Vieja - Cuban Shredded Beef
steps: Cook beef until tender and shred it.
Fry onions and peppers.
Add tomato sauce and shredded beef.
Simmer until flavors blend.
Serve with rice.

name: Borscht - Russian Beet Soup
steps: Cook beets and vegetables in broth.
Simmer until soft.
Season and serve hot.
Optional: add sour cream.

name: Pierogi - Polish Filled Dumplings
steps: Prepare dough and roll it thin.
Fill with mashed potatoes and onions.
Boil until dumplings float.
Optional: fry lightly.
Serve warm.

name: Swedish Meatballs - Kottbullar
steps: Mix meat, breadcrumbs, onion and cream.
Shape small balls.
Fry until golden.
Serve with cream sauce.
note: Served with mashed potatoes or pasta.

name: Jollof Rice - Nigerian Spiced Tomato Rice
steps: Blend tomatoes, pepper and onion.
Cook mixture in oil.
Add rice and water.
Simmer until rice absorbs sauce.
Serve hot.
note: Most famous West African rice dish.

name: Lamington - Australian Coconut Chocolate Cake
steps: Cut sponge cake into cubes.
Dip each cube in chocolate icing.
Roll in desiccated coconut.
Let set before serving.
note: Classic Australian dessert often served at school events and fairs.

name: Pavlova - Meringue with Cream and Fruit
steps: Beat egg whites and sugar to stiff peaks.
Add cornstarch and vinegar.
Bake low until crisp outside and soft inside.
Top with whipped cream and fresh fruits.
note: National dessert of New Zealand, light and airy.

name: Bobotie - South African Spiced Meat Bake
steps: Cook onion and minced meat with curry and seasoning.
Mix meat with squeezed bread.
Place in baking dish.
Pour egg and milk mixture on top.
Bake until golden and set.
note: Traditional Cape Malay dish served with yellow rice.

name: Doro Wat - Ethiopian Spicy Chicken Stew
steps: Cook onions slowly in oil until very soft.
Add berbere and tomato paste, cook a few minutes.
Add chicken pieces and coat in sauce.
Add water and simmer until meat is tender.
Serve with boiled eggs and flatbread.
note: Signature Ethiopian dish usually eaten with injera.

name: Nyama Choma - Kenyan Grilled Meat
steps: Marinate meat with lemon, garlic, ginger, salt and pepper.
Grill over charcoal or in oven until cooked.
Serve with simple salad and ugali or bread.

name: Thieboudienne - Senegalese Fish and Rice
steps: Prepare a tomato-based sauce with vegetables and spices.
Cook fish gently in the sauce.
Remove fish and cook rice in the same broth.
Serve rice on a large platter with vegetables and fish on top.
note: Often considered the national dish of Senegal.

name: Kabsa - Saudi Spiced Rice with Meat
steps: Brown meat with onions and spices.
Add tomato paste and water, simmer until meat is almost tender.
Add rice to the broth.
Cook until rice absorbs liquid and meat is fully cooked.
Serve on a large platter.
note: Festive rice dish served across the Arabian Peninsula.

name: Mansaf - Jordanian Lamb with Yogurt Sauce
ingredients: Jameed or dried yogurt or thick yogurt sauce
steps: Cook lamb in water with salt and spices until tender.
Prepare yogurt sauce and mix some broth with it.
Cook rice separately.
Serve rice on large tray, top with lamb and yogurt sauce.
Garnish with roasted nuts.
note: National dish of Jordan, served at big gatherings.

name: Chicken Adobo - Filipino Vinegar Soy Stew
steps: Marinate chicken in soy sauce, vinegar, garlic and spices.
Brown chicken in a pot.
Add marinade and a little water.
Simmer until chicken is tender and sauce reduced.
Serve with white rice.
note: Probably the most famous dish of the Philippines.

name: Nasi Lemak - Malaysian Coconut Rice Plate
steps: Cook rice with coconut milk, water, salt and pandan leaf.
Arrange rice on plate.
Serve with boiled egg, fried anchovies, peanuts and cucumber.
Add spicy sambal on the side.
note: Considered the national dish of Malaysia, often eaten for breakfast.

name: Hainanese Chicken Rice - Singapore Classic
steps: Simmer chicken gently with ginger and garlic.
Cook rice using chicken broth and aromatics.
Slice chicken and drizzle with soy mix.
Serve with rice, broth and chili sauce.
note: Singaporeâs most iconic dish, simple and flavorful.

name: Nasi Goreng - Indonesian Fried Rice
steps: Fry garlic, onion and chili paste.
Add rice and soy sauce.
Add vegetables or chicken if desired.
Push aside and cook eggs, then mix everything.
note: Indonesiaâs national fried rice â smoky, fast and delicious.

name: Pad Thai - Thai Stir-Fried Noodles
steps: Soak noodles in warm water.
Stir-fry garlic, egg and protein.
Add noodles and tamarind/soy mix.
Toss with bean sprouts and peanuts.
Serve hot with lime wedges.
note: One of the worldâs most famous Thai dishes.

name: Pho - Vietnamese Noodle Soup
steps: Simmer bones with onion, ginger and spices.
Cook rice noodles separately.
Slice beef or chicken thin.
Assemble "bowl": noodles, meat, hot broth.
Garnish with herbs and lime.
note: Vietnamâs national soup, aromatic and comforting.

name: Okonomiyaki - Japanese Savory Pancake
steps: Mix flour, eggs and water to make a batter.
Add cabbage.
Cook on pan with pork/shrimp on top.
Flip and finish cooking.
Top with sauce and mayo.

name: Bibimbap - Korean Mixed Rice Bowl
steps: Cook each vegetable separately.
Place rice in a bowl.
Arrange vegetables neatly on top.
Add fried egg and gochujang.
Mix before eating.
note: Healthy Korean dish mixing vegetables, rice and chili paste.

name: Nihari - Pakistani Slow-Cooked Meat Stew
steps: Brown onion in ghee.
Add meat and spices.
Add water and cook slowly for several hours.
Thicken with flour paste.
Serve with ginger and lemon.
note: Rich breakfast stew traditionally eaten on weekends.

name: Bhuna Khichuri - Spiced Rice and Lentils
steps: Fry onions and spices.
Add rice and lentils.
Cook with water until soft and thick.
Serve warm.
note: Popular rainy-day comfort dish in Bangladesh.

name: Koshari - Egyptian Lentils, Rice & Pasta
steps: Cook rice, lentils and pasta separately.
Layer rice, lentils and pasta on plate.
Top with tomato sauce and crispy onions.
Add chili sauce if desired.

name: Iskender Kebab - Turkish Yogurt Tomato Dish
ingredients: Thin sliced grilled beef or lamb
steps: Place grilled meat slices on toasted bread pieces.
Pour hot tomato-butter sauce on top.
Add yogurt on the side.
Drizzle melted butter before serving.
note: Famous specialty from Bursa, rich and flavorful.
